author: sky.cactus
content: Heh, I consider that a different order of magnitude, but I'm convinced it is a "dangerous" order still.

author: sky.cactus
content: Miners can set the gas limit to any number they want on a block they mine as long as it is within 1/1024 of the previous block's gas limit.

author: sky.cactus
content: So each block can change the gas limit by 1/1024th of the parent block.

author: foobar0x
content: Interesting, so isn't there a greedy incentive to always make the next block 1/1024 bigger? Why isn't that happening today? There are certainly enough transactions in the mempool to fill larger blocks.

author: sky.cactus
content: If 100% of hashing power targets the same target, it can up to double or half every ~3 hours.

author: sky.cactus
content:
The suspicion is a combination of:
1. Miners aren't all dicks like some people believe.
2. Miners know that if they behave against users, there will be a fork that takes away their power.

author: sky.cactus
content: (my math from above: `12.5 * (1 + 1/1024)^x = 50`, solving for x gives ~1420 which is about 6 hours of blocks)
